articleHTML:
Despite its relative proximity to Downtown Oakland, Reinhardt Redwood Regional Park was—before today—a park to which I had only ever driven or, twice, done a somewhat long run to only to arrive at the park in time to run a mile turn around to head home.

I now realize this has been a huge loss on my part, as the 33 bus from Downtown Oakland cuts off a 3.5 mile approach in hardly ten minutes! Though it doesn't sound like much, that's seven miles out and back which you can then replace with trails!

Downtown Oakland

The moment I stepped onto the 33 bus, I exposed myself as a newbie. After I unsuccesffully rubbed my Clipper Card all over the change machine, the bus driver smiled and pointed to the correct card reader.

Park Boulevard

The bus takes you 3.5 miles up the hill in hardly ten minutes, dropping you off on Park Boulevard, along a string of local trail systems. While a perfectly fine destination in their own right, the trails inject you into the parks with just over a mile of running and not more than a few steps on asphalt.

In a slight misstep, I completely forgot where I had previously entered the trail system and, expecting to simply drop right onto a trail, instead found myself standing next to a bridge, looking down a steep slope to the trail a hundred feet below. It wasn't bad, but I wouldn't recommend it. Any reasonable map like Gaia GPS will put you in a much better position.

The running was only marginally better at the bottom of the ravine, although the trail—which is a somewhat charitable label for the boulder-strewn, half-dry creek bed—got me to my destination. The trail along the west side of the ravine turns out to be somewhat better, but then I'm a person who loves things that are neither actually trails nor actually "runnable."

The Palos Colorado Trail looks on the map like little more than a drainage ditch en route to better things, but it's really quite a stunning, redwood-lined little gorge. Judging by the foot traffic, there's no shortage of people who come here just for this section of the park.

As you climb out of the gorge, the views across the valley are equally charming. The protected valleys make it a fine run for a sunny day, but it only really shows off is on a dim, foggy morning when the dewfall amounts to a light rain and the eucalyptus-lined hills disappear into the clouds.

Even the connector trails are lovely.

At 1619 feet above sea level, Redwood Peak amounts to little more than some boulders in a forest. In fact the whole park, to the best of my knowledge, offers hardly more than the slightest glimpse of any wide-angle vista.

The views of trees lost in fog are second to none though.

From Redwood Peak, the trail decends 800 feet to the Valley Trail. Although it offers an uncommonly flat trail through the hills, I prefer a somewhat contrived route which bounces between three parallel trails: the Valley Trail which follows the bottom of the valley, the French Trail which winds along halfway up the ridge, and the West Ridge Trail which follows the entire ridge.

The next incline is the Chown Trail (which I can only imagine where the name came from). The combination of steep incline and sharp switchbacks which place you in the treetops make it my favorite trail in the Bay Area. If you bring a headlamp and run slightly after sunset, you may even catch the coyotes performing their evening howling.

The section of the West Ridge Trail is a bit uneventful but on a nice foggy day still doesn't disappoint.

After decending into the valley and passing the bathrooms, playground, and parking area, the trail climbs to the East Ridge Trail and offers (at last!) nearly a couple miles of relatively uninterrupted running.

One of my favorite views in the park is the West Ridge, seen on a foggy day from the East Ridge.

Fire prevention is rarely so cute.

Separated by hardly a half mile, the East Ridge Trail is a completely different ecosystem. Microclimates!

Every trip into Redwood Regional must, inevitably, end with a climb back up out of the valley. It's painful no matter what, so I like to embrace it and take the somewhat more arduous section of the French Trail to add a couple hundred additional feet of climbing.

Redwood Regional rarely pokes out of the clouds, more often just sitting in the fog. Even as the sun speeds toward burning away the fog, you can often skip the sunscreen and find yourself running in a light late-morning dew-fed rain.

A foggy day is enough to activate the eucalyptus scent.

I was susprised to see as many people on the Palos Colorado Trail as in other sections of the park. Really, it's surprisingly lovely.

The tunnel under Highway 13 is a welcome sight. I spent a bit more time choosing my route on the return trip and was able to avoid any off-trail antics.

Park Boulevard

Downtown Oakland

Back
